items.item_details: For immediate releaseSeptember 24, 2007Contact: Larry_Slonaker, SCCOE(408) 453-6662Santa Clara County's Finest TeachersHonored on Teacher Recognition DaySAN JOSE, CA – Thirty "Teachers of the Year" from Santa Clara County school districts will be applauded by colleagues and community leaders at the countywide 39th Annual Teacher Recognition Day awards ceremony, Monday, Sept. 24, at 7 p.m. at the Heritage Theatre in Campbell.Honorees were selected by their districts for the most prestigious local award given to classroom teachers. The recognition ceremony, presented by the Santa Clara County Office of Education, is the oldest and largest of its kind in California.The 2007 honorees include teachers of every grade from kindergarten through high school. Some have taught for as few as eight years, three for as many as 40 years. The gala ceremony will be co-hosted by Superintendent Wilcox and by community leader and education advocate Brian Adams. Honorees will be presented with engraved awards and various gifts, entertained by student performers, and featured in video profiles.

items.item_details: Dorothy Wright Teaching AwardsThe Dorothy Wright Outstanding Teaching Awards were established in 1987 as a memorial to a former member of the Department of English who distinguished herself for her commitment to teacher education. Professor Wright taught at San Jose State for 30 years before retiring in 1987.What gives the award its unique character is that its recipients are nominated by former students. To identify worthy candidates, the English Department circulates questionnaires in its freshman composition courses, asking students to identify those teachers who best prepared them for their college writing courses (see questionnaire below). Hundreds of the questionnaires are collected and tabulated; then the award recipients are honored in a campus ceremony--usually in early May--attended by the English Department faculty, students, and other members of the university community. The English Department at San Jose University considers it a privilege to sponsor the Dorothy Wright Awards, not only because many of its recipients are former graduates of its program, but because the program allows it to make the acquaintance of many of the most inspiring members of the area's educational community. The success of the English Department's own program rests upon the dedication and idealism of the area's English teachers. The Dorothy Wright Awards, therefore, honor not only the recipients but all teachers engaged in our common enterprise.Awards were presented to the following teachers from East Side Union High School District:Valerie Arbizu, Evergreen Valley High SchoolMonique Childs, Piedmont Hills High SchoolNancy Galindo, Yerba Buena High SchoolHarriet Garcia Rousseau, Independence High SchoolJohn Herrera, Independence High SchoolMarie Milner, Andrew Hill High SchoolNancy Schwalen, Santa Teresa High SchoolMichael Winsatt, Andrew Hill High SchoolGary Zellner, Silver Creek High School

items.item_details: Dear Mr. Nunez, Mr. Moser, Ms. Williams and Ms. Hanson: I am delighted to report to you that Mr. Rey Enriquez, Math Teacher at PHHS has been awarded the Santa Clara Valley Math Association Teacher of the Year Award. A few pictures and the banquet program is attached. It makes all of us proud of this achievement, and that's why I took the liberty to advise you in this email of this award.  As parents, we were happy to recommend Mr. Rey Enriquez for the SCVMA Teacher of the Year Award. He has been the Math teacher of our son, Manav Kumar, for the past two years for Calculus AB/AP in freshman and Calculus BC/AP currently in sophomore year, along with being the advisor to PHHS Math Club of which Manav is a member.    As we saw first-hand, Mr. Enriquez’s strongest characteristics were his passion for Mathematics and a drive to provide opportunities outside of the classroom to students to shine out. The Math curriculum at Piedmont includes AP classes and voluntary Math Club. Mr. Enriquez has been outstanding in keeping up with the AP workload, encouraging students to compete in Math competitions and producing results which any parent would be proud of. We are!

items.item_details: The following two people were approved by Bob via Executive Cabinet to be honored at the May Board meeting on May 22, 2008: Rob Mieso, Coordinator, Outreach/relations with Schools from DeAnza College. He not only has three teens in our high schools (2 at Silver Creek and one in the ACCEL program at EVCC), he has also been an advocate for doing college outreach for ESUHSD Latinos and African American students. At any moment, he brought us “stuff” for us to include in our district sponsored conferences and he just informed us yesterday that he is going to allocate “transportation” scholarships for at least 50 ESUHSD students who wish to attend DeAnza next year. Victor Garza, Jr., ENLACE Outreach/Recruitment Specialist from Evergreen Valley College. This fall he provided four of our high schools with student leadership training and also sponsors a group of students from Yerba Buena with counseling and outreach support. He has provided a workshop for our Latino Parent Coalition, and has also assisted the Latino Ambassadors with information and assistance for their conference. Whenever we send a student to him for assistance whether the student is going to attend Evergreen or not, he willing counsels and assists the student.

This “supplement” section to BP 1312 incorporates the recent requirements of EC 35186 (Williams: SB550 and AB2727), which requires a different complaint form and timeline.  Additionally, it is required that staff bring to the Board of Trustees a quarterly report of Williams complaints filed and their current disposition.  The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from January 1, 2008 through March 31, 2008.  Attached, also, is a chart summarizing the nature and resolution of these complaints. items.item_details: Attached please find the proposed classified, classified management and certificated Administrative holiday schedule for the 2008-2009 school calendar.CSEA, on behalf of classified employees, and the District have reached a tentative agreement on the holiday schedule and are requesting final approval from the Board of Trustees. The proposed holiday schedule includes the contractual holidays, plus three additional paid holidays during Christmas break.  It also includes two days during the Christmas break where bargaining unit members will have the option of charging annual leave, floating holiday, compensatory time or leave without pay. This arrangement will enable the District to shutdown all operations during the two-week break, which will result in a savings in utility costs.FISCAL IMPACT FUNDING SOURCEAs per salary schedule						VariousRECOMMENDATIONIt is recommended that the Board adopt/approve the classified, classified management and certificated administrative holiday calendar schedule for the 2008-2009 school year.Attachment MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDINGBetweenCalifornia School Employees Association, Chapter #187AndEast Side Union High School District**PENDING**

items.item_details: Pursuant to the student school calendar presented to the Board, February 20, 2009 was set as the date the District would observe Lincoln’s Birthday.  By law, the observance of the Lincoln’s Birthday should be held on February 12, 2009, unless modified through the current legal process, which in this case is through the passage of a resolution.RECOMMENDATIONIt is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt resolution #2007-2008-41 declaring the observance of Lincoln’s Birthday on Friday, February 20, 2009.EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTResolution #2007-2008-41Declaring the Observance of Lincoln’s Birthday onFebruary 20, 2009WHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees adopted the 2008-2009 school calendar on April 17, 2008 with the observance of Lincoln’s Birthday on Friday, February 20, 2009, which differed from Education Code 37220, subdivision (a); andWHEREAS, revisions in Education Code 37220 allow the Governing Board to revise the date that schools are closed in observance of any holiday identified in subdivision (a) through the adoption of a resolution; andWHEREAS, the observance of the chosen holiday on the day designated will least affect student average daily attendance and the budget plan of the district;NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the Board of Trustees of the East Side Union High School District has determined the observance of Lincoln’s Birthday to be on February 20, 2009, for all district schools instead of February 12, 2009.ADOPTED and approved this day of May 22, 2008AYES:		 NOES:		 ABSENT:	    Clerk of the Board    Date

items.item_details: Approve Resolution #2007/2008-43 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of General Obligation Bonds, 2008 Election, Series A, (Measure E) in a PrincipalAmount not to exceed $50,000,000East Side Union High School District wishes to institute proceedings to authorize the issuance and sale of a first series of its General Obligation Bonds which were authorized by the voters at the February 5, 2008 election.  The District proposes to issue the bonds in the aggregate principal amount not to exceed $50 million.  The Series A bonds will be issued under the Government Code (beginning at Section 53506), which allows the District to issue the bonds directly rather than through the Board of Supervisors of the County.The proceeds of the Bonds will be applied by the District for acquisition and construction of educational facilities to be used for the educational purposes of the District, which is in accordance with the ballot proposition as authorized by the voters.FINANCIAL IMPACT: FUNDING SOURCE:$50,000,000 (Not to Exceed)						Measure ERECOMMENDATION:It is recommended the Board of Trustees approve Resolution #2007/2008-43 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of General Obligation Bonds, 2008 Election, Series A, (Measure E) in a Principal Amount not to exceed $50,000,000.

items.item_details: STRS Exemption Certification – Emergency Employment of Retired MemberOVERVIEWAndrew Hill High School was undergoing its third administrative transition for the 2006-2007 school year.  The Student Advisory position had been vacant for eight months and is an important member of the safety team.  At the time Andrew Hill was experiencing an increase in gang violence and crime activity.  The concern for the safety of the student population was a priority.   These circumstances constitute an emergency situation as provided for in Education Code Section 24216 which allows for the employment of retired administrator for a period not to exceed 2 years; although this is not an administrative position the circumstances warrant a need for a Student Advisor with years of experience.  Such employment will not constitute reinstatement of the retired member as an active member in the State Teachers Retirement System.  Included is the Exemption Certificate which describes the circumstances.RECOMMENDATIONApprove the employment of Felipe C. Venegas, a retired STRS member, as a Student Advisor in accordance with Education Code Section 24216 with the exception of it not being an administrative position.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTBOARD RESOLUTION NO. #2007/2008-46IN SUPPORT OF MEASURE “G” APPROVING THE ISSUANCE OF SCHOOL BONDS FOR THE ALUM ROCK UNION ELEMENTARY SCHOOL DISTRICTWHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District (“District”) is the largest high school district in San Jose and its surrounding areas;WHEREAS, there are seven K-8 school districts within the jurisdictional boundaries of the District whose students feed into and are within the attendance boundaries of the District (the “Feeder K-8 School Districts”);WHEREAS, Alum Rock Union Elementary School District (“ARUSD”) is one such Feeder K-8 School District and operates 24 schools within its jurisdiction;WHEREAS, the ARUSD schools are, on average, over 40 years old and in need of major upgrades and repairs to make safety and security improvements, and provide District children with modern classrooms and technology;WHEREAS, the District and ARUSD share common goals for increasing student achievement and facilitating the transition from elementary to middle school and from middle to high school to ensure the greatest possibilities of academic success for all students; WHEREAS, Measure G on the June 3, 2008, election ballot would, if approved by voters, authorize the ARUSD to issue up to $179,000,000 in bonds to renovate, acquire, construct, repair and equip schools, sites and facilities, with required independent financial audits and citizens' oversight, to create better and safer learning environments and greater educational opportunities for the ARUSD and District community;NOW THEREFORE, IT IS HEREBY RESOLVED THAT:The Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District supports the passage of, and encourages the approval of, Measure G on the June 3, 2008, ballot by the District community.  Adopted by the East Side Union High School District Governing Board on May 15, 2008.By the following vote:AYES:	____NOES:	____ABSTAIN:	____ABSENT:	____						_______________________________ Clerk of the Governing Board of the						East Side Union High School District

items.item_details: BackgroundThe 4-year Master Business Relationship Agreements (MBRA) entered into by MetroED and its participating districts will expire on June 30, 2008.In November of 2006, the participating districts approved an amendment #2 to the MBRA that implemented a new funding model for CCOC that would equalize, over a 4-year period, support funding for the students attending CCOC.  The equalization process was to be funded by growth ADA granted to MetroED by the state.  During early 2007-08, MetroED received word that the expected growth ADA (and related funding) would not be forthcoming.  Consequently, discussions opened with the MetroED Executive Council (participating district Superintendents) for purposes of developing a new funding model.  On April 21, 2008, the MetroED Governing Board and Executive Council, including the participating district Chief Business Officials, met in a joint meeting to discuss the Equalization process and progress on renewing the MBRA.  At that meeting, the superintendents signed a memorandum of understanding agreeing to that which is stipulated on the attached Memorandum of Understanding dated April 21, 2008.FINANCIAL IMPACT: FUNDING SOURCE:None in 2008-2009			                                                             N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the one year extension of the Master Business Relationship Agreement between East Side Union High School District and MetroED as stipulated for the 2008-2009 FY.AttachmentAG:va

items.item_details: Administration recommends the Board conditionally approve the purchase of the Calero School site, 420 Calero Avenue, San Jose, CA, from the Oak Grove Elementary School District.  The Calero site consists of approximately 10 acres of real property with 32,900 square feet of building improvements (classrooms and associated facilities), and open space field/recreational areas thereon.  The Board previously authorized Administration to enter into negotiations with the Oak Grove School District (“OGSD”) for the possible purchase of the site.  After negotiations, OGSD now proposes to sell the site to ESUHSD for $20,000,000.Administration proposes to use the site for a future Community Day School and/or other programs to be operated by the District and/or to house one or more of the District’s charter school programs.District and OGSD continue to negotiate the form of purchase contract.  The obligation to purchase will be subject to ESUHSD’s inspection of the site to determine that the site and improvements are in acceptable condition for use by ESUHSD. The source of funds for the purchase will be Measure E bond proceeds.RECOMMENDATIONApprove the purchase of Calero School Site for $20,000,000, subject to Administration and legal counsel negotiating acceptable form of purchase contract.FISCAL IMPACT FUNDING SOURCE$20,000,000	Measure E bond funds

items.item_details:
In July 1994, the Commission on Teacher Credentialing changed the process for emergency credentialing.  Prior to that time, districts were required to issue individual statements of need for each applicant.  The applicant, in turn, would take the declaration of need to the county office of education for the issuance of an emergency credential. This applies to the following credentials or authorizations: Emergency CLAD, BCLAD, Resource Specialist, Library Media, Clinical or Rehabilitative Permits.Now, the Commission issues a permit to an individual who qualifies for an emergency based on the district’s Declaration of Need.  This Declaration, approved by the local Board of Trustees, is submitted to the Commission once a year.  Emergency permits, although originally used primarily to staff partial assignments and special education, now help fill the fully credentialed teacher gap created by class size reduction and statewide teacher shortage.  Every attempt is being made to hire credentialed teachers before considering people on emergency permits.  Attached is the Commission on Teacher Credentialing form titled Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.  Pursuant to direction from the county office of education’s credential’s office, the district is over estimating the number of permits it might require in order to cover any unanticipated needs that might occur during the course of the 2008/09 school year.FISCAL IMPACT FUNDING SOURCENot Applicable						Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATIONIt is recommended that the Governing Board approve the Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.
Our adopted rules of Parliamentary Procedure, Robert's Rules, provide for a consent agenda listing several items for approval of the Board by a single motion.  Most of the items listed under the consent agenda have gone through Board subcommittee review and recommendation.  Documentation concerning these items has been provided to all Board members and the public in advance to assure an extensive and thorough review.  Items may be removed from the consent agenda at the request of any board member.
Motion & Voting
To approve the entire consent agenda.
Motion by Clerk Shirakawa, second by Vice President Garcia.
Final Resolution: Motion Carries
Yea: President Nguyen, Vice President Garcia, Clerk Shirakawa, Member Biehl, Member Herrera

items.item_details: DESCRIPTION: Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student’s parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:1)	An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.2)	Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.3)	An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination while using a modification that fundamentally alters what the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students’ parents.The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in Education Code Section 60851: Student items.item_details: Overview:The Carl D. Perkins Vocational Education Act of 1998, under Section 131 – Secondary Education, has recommended East Side Union High School District for funding for 2008-2009.  The Perkins Act directs us to: (1) continuously upgrade and improve vocational career-technical education programs, (2) integrate academies with vocational education through a coherent sequence of courses to ensure learning in the core academic and technical subjects, (3) provide students with strong experience and understanding of all aspects of an industry, (4) develop, improve, or expand the use of technology in career technical education, (5) provide professional development to vocational teachers, administrators, and counselors, and (6) develop and implement evaluations of vocational and technical education programs carried out with Perkins funds, including assessment of how the needs of special populations are being met.Accomplishments:In our Local Plan/Application for the Perkins Act, each school site has identified and/or developed integrated career programs in the form of academies or magnet programs, identified and trained teacher teams, and continued with the integration of instruction through incorporation of core subject standards and relevancy activities.  We have also refined our Quality Criteria and Standards for Career-Technical Education programs, established career exploration and assessment activities, developed transition sequences to post secondary study, implemented skill certification programs, and developed a support academy for special education students.Our integrated career paths and academies are aligned with state career incentives.  These include increasing access for special population students, implementing activities to ensure that students are developing employability skills, and increasing work-based learning opportunities for studentsFISCAL IMPACT FUNDING SOURCE $548,418 Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Technical Education Act of 1998, Funding for 2008-2009, PL 105-332RECOMMENDATIONIt is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the District’s annual application and Local Plan for Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Technical Act Funding for 2008-2009 in the amount of $548,418.00

items.item_details: BACKGROUND The Gifted and Talented Education (GATE) program is authorized under California Education Code (EC) sections 52200-52212 and California Code of Regulations (CCR) sections 3820-33870. The purpose of the GATE program is to provide funding for local educational agencies (LEAs) to develop unique opportunities for high-achieving and underachieving pupils in California public elementary and secondary schools that have been identified as gifted and talented. It is the intent of the legislature that special efforts are made to ensure that pupils from economically disadvantaged and varying cultural backgrounds are provided with full participation in the program. It is also the intent of the legislature that the quality of programs for gifted and talented pupils be improved and to provide for the experimentation in the delivery of programs including a variety of programmatic approaches and cost levels to provide for the identification of gifted and talented pupils by individual school districts in a variety of ways. (EC 52200[a][b])  FISCAL IMPACT FUNDING SOURCENone                                                                                                N/A    RECOMMENDATIONSIt is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the application for the Gifted and Talented Education (GATE) Program for 2008-2009.

Operational Items/Board Discussion and/or ActionInformation : 8.01 Budget and Staff Reduction Update – Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentThis week a number of employees went up to Sacramento to talk to Legislators about education in East Side Union High School District. Superintendent Nuñez shared photos of the three East Side teams who meet with Legislators.Superintendent Nuñez with the District’s attorney, tax attorneys, County Office of Education and our District Auditor found there are ways to use bond dollars to pay for positions within those bonds.  We will be looking at those dollars to pay for some of the position that are identified for layoff or reduction that are currently being paid out of the general fund.  The Superintendent also commented 1802 monies could be carryover next year.  We will be able to carry over $1,000,000 to next year’s budget.  We will need to get additional monies from the State for one-time dollars; otherwise we may be facing the same financial concerns.  Superintendent Nuñez announced the District will be reinstating the following certificated positions:·       Student Advisors:                            	9.0 FTEs  (Independence 4; James Lick 1; all others 2)·       Counselors:                                     	13.0 FTEs  (All) ·       Librarians:                                      	The District will be allocating a .2 FTE at each site.·       Teachers on Special Assignment: 	2.0 FTEs (Post Senior & Workability Prog; Workability Prog) Superintendent Nuñez also announced the District will be reinstating the following classified positions:·       Accounting Technicians:         	3.0 FTEs  (All)·       Career Center Technicians:     	7.19 FTEs  (All)·       School Bus Drivers:                 	4 Positions·       School Community Liaisons:   	4.0 FTEs·       Staff Secretaries:                     	2.0 FTEs  (All) We will wait until the May Revise to be announced by the Governor before we determine if additional positions can be returned.  Everyone is encouaged to continue notifying State Legislators about the importance of education and the detrimental impact the State budget cuts will have on education.  The Superintendent will be inviting Maria Shriver to come and meet with East Side representatives regarding the impact on education as a result of the State budget.Vice President Eddie Garcia spoke regarding the visit to Sacramento.  He thanked the students who wrote thousand of letters to the Governor.  East Side was well represented in Sacramento.  East Side has a true voice in Assembly Member Joe Coto for East Side.  His support and escort to the Governor’s Office provided the team access to deliver the thousands of letters to the Governor’s Office.  Member Herrera echoed his appreciation to the Superintendent and the team.Member Biehl thanked members of the delegation for going to Sacramento.  He also said the Californians for Justice recently held an event that was televised.  Everyone is doing all that they can to find dollars.  Clerk Shirakawa congratulated all those who have been reinstated.  He asked that we keep pushing our consultant for resources.  We need to keep fighting for ourselves and our District.  President Nguyen thanked the Superintendent and his staff for all their support in working diligently on the budget.  He complimented the Superintendent and Counsel.Information : 8.02 Presentation on Citizens Bond Oversight Committee Measure G – Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities and John Moore, Chairperson of Bond Oversight Committee John Moore, former Chairperson of the Bond Oversight Committee gave a presentation on Measure G.
